root.publications: Egerod, Søren. 1991. Far Eastern Languages. In Sydney M. Lamb & E. Douglas Mitchell (eds.), Sprung from Some Common Source, 205-231. Stanford, California: Stanford University Press.

child.pub-comments: "Sinitic (= Chinese), consisting of many languages ("Chinese dialects")" (Egerod 1991:207). The author does not specify whether the branches of Sinitic that he provides here are individual languages or subgroups, so for the purposes of this tree they are represented as dialect groups in order to reflect the possibility of broader membership in this group as well as the differing terminology of the various lects being called 'languages' or 'dialects'.
child.publications: Egerod, Søren. 1991. Far Eastern Languages. In Sydney M. Lamb & E. Douglas Mitchell (eds.), Sprung from Some Common Source, 205-231. Stanford, California: Stanford University Press.

child.pub-comments: "In the very south of China the Sinitic Yuè languages are spoken, of which Cantonese (Canton = Guǎngzhōu) is best known (it is also the standard language of Hong Kong and Macau)" (Egerod 1991:213).
child.geography: In the very south of China
child.publications: Egerod, Søren. 1991. Far Eastern Languages. In Sydney M. Lamb & E. Douglas Mitchell (eds.), Sprung from Some Common Source, 205-231. Stanford, California: Stanford University Press.

child.pub-comments: "In the very south of China the Sinitic Yuè languages are spoken, of which Cantonese (Canton = Guǎngzhōu) is best known (it is also the standard language of Hong Kong and Macau)" (Egerod 1991:213).

child.pub-comments: Author notes that Karenic "may however have sprung from the Sinitic side" (Egerod 1991:207).
child.publications: Egerod, Søren. 1991. Far Eastern Languages. In Sydney M. Lamb & E. Douglas Mitchell (eds.), Sprung from Some Common Source, 205-231. Stanford, California: Stanford University Press.
